citations.narrative:
One (1) adult male common marmoset was consigned for auction without proof of a health certificate. Health certificates
are important for ensuring that animals are healthy, fit for travel, and appear free of any infectious disease or physical
abnormality that would be a danger to themselves, other animals, and the public. A health certificate issued by a licensed
veterinarian, dated not more than 10 days prior to the transportation, must accompany all non-human primates.
Correct by: Sept. 9, 2025

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport nonhuman primates.
citations.narrative:
One (1) adult male common marmoset was housed in a travel-style pet crate for its transport enclosure. The openings of
the door (approx. 1x1 inch square) and ventilation openings along the sides were big enough to allow the nonhuman
primate to extend its arms or other body parts outside the transport enclosure.
Openings large enough for nonhuman primate(s) to extend parts of its body through can lead to injury of the nonhuman
primate(s) or to other animals or people nearby.
Primary enclosures used to transport nonhuman primates must be constructed so that the nonhuman primates are at all
times securely contained within the enclosure and cannot put any body parts outside the enclosure in a way that could
result in injury to the animals, or to persons or animals nearby.
Correct by: Sept. 9, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
This inspection was conducted at the Triple W Livestock Auction in Cookeville, TN.
Additional Inspectors:
TANESHA WILKINS, SACS n

narrative:
2.78(a) 
   
Health certification and identification. 
One (1) adult male common marmoset was consigned for auction without proof of a health certificate. Health certificates 
are important for ensuring that animals are healthy, fit for travel, and appear free of any infectious disease or physical 
abnormality that would be a danger to themselves, other animals, and the public. A health certificate issued by a licensed 
veterinarian, dated not more than 10 days prior to the transportation, must accompany all non-human primates.  
Correct by: Sept. 9, 2025 
3.87(a)(3) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport nonhuman primates. 
One (1) adult male common marmoset was housed in a travel-style pet crate for its transport enclosure. The openings of 
the door (approx. 1x1 inch square) and ventilation openings along the sides were big enough to allow the nonhuman 
primate to extend its arms or other body parts outside the transport enclosure.  
 
Openings large enough for nonhuman primate(s) to extend parts of its body through can lead to injury of the nonhuman 
primate(s) or to other animals or people nearby.  
 
Primary enclosures used to transport nonhuman primates must be constructed so that the nonhuman primates are at all 
times securely contained within the enclosure and cannot put any body parts outside the enclosure in a way that could 
result in injury to the animals, or to persons or animals nearby.  
Correct by: Sept. 9, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative. 
 
This inspection was conducted at the Triple W Livestock Auction in Cookeville, TN.

Additional Inspectors: 
TANESHA WILKINS, SACS n
